TextEquiv.Unicode: The Birmingham Daily Post.
VOL. I. No. 16.
BIRMINGHAM, FRIDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1857.
PRICE ONE PENNY.
INDIA.
THE RELIEF OF LUCKNOW.
[From the Times.]
“ We hear that the relief of Lucknow was achieved with the loss of only four oﬃcers killed and forty wounded, and that Sir Colin Campbels force amounted to 12,000.
" The Abeona, with the 94th Regiment, arrived at Malta from Plymouth on the 20th, and left for Alexandria on the same day.
" The mails for Australia arrived on the 21st, and left for Alexandria on the 22nd.
" The Desperate is under orders to relieve the Centaur at Naples."
UNITED STATES.
RESUMPTION OF SPECIE PAYMENTS.
The steam‑ship Fulton arrived at Southampton on Wed‑ nesday night, with the American mails, and advices from New York to the 12th instant.
Amongst her cargo is specie to the value of 427,000 dol‑ lars for England, and 124,000 dollars for France. Amongst the passengers is Lola Montes, on her way to Paris.

The news from Mexico states that the position of the Government had improved. The reactionary force had been defeated by the Government troops. Comonfort and the Supreme Court were formally installed. The port of Navi‑ dad had been declared open to commerce.

A number of bank oﬃcers at New York had met, and resolved to resume specie payments in full on all their lia‑ bilities. This resolution was prompted by the announce‑ ment that the Bank of America, the Bank of Commerce, the Manhattan and National Banks, had resolved to resume payment on the 13th instant.

The total specie reserve amounts to 26,000 dollars. The deposits have not increased much during the last two or three weeks. The suspension of specie payments is now rather nominal than actual. "The banks pay specie over their own counter for bills and small cheques, and the com‑ munity gets along very well with that. When business revives, it will be a more diﬃcult matter to carry on the operations of trade without a general resumption."

The Secretary for the Treasury has proposed to supply an issue of treasury notes not to exceed 20,000,000 dollars. He also proposes the passage of a compulsory Bankrupt Act, by which insolvent banks and railway companies may be wound up, whether they like it or not.
There has been a skirmish between Colonel Alexander's forces and the Mormons. A large force is sent against the latter, and a protracted war is considered inevitable.
The amount in the Treasury is 6,000,000 dollars. The receipts for the week ending the 7th instant were about half a million of dollars.
Fitzpatrick had been elected President of the Senate. All the democratic candidates for oﬃces of the house were elected with great unanimity. James L. Orr, of South Carolina, was elected Speaker.

Owing to the mild weather the canals were not to be closed before the 15th instant. The amount and value of Ameri‑ can produce retained in the interior at the close of this year will be the largest ever known in the history of the country.
In freights, rates were ﬁrmer for grain to Liverpool. Sugar was ﬁrm and corn active. Freights were drooping. Exchange on London, 103 to 105.
ITALY.

A letter from Rome, of the 12th instant, in the Con‑ stitutionnel, says: "The Consistory is ﬁxed for the 17th, but contrary to the expectation of all interested, there will be no creation of new cardinals. The principal event of the meeting will be the announcement of the birth of an heir to the throne of Spain, and the nomination of Mon‑ signor Falinelli Antoniani, Bishop of Forli, to be Papal Nuncio at the Brazils. The Grand Duchess Helen, of Russia, arrived here the day before yesterday, and will remain during the greater part of the winter. She intends to live as retired as possible. It is generally expected that the sale of the rich collection of antiquities of the Marquis de Campina, whose defalcation is the subject of general conversation, will fully cover the deﬁcit in his accounts. During some excavations lately made at a place called the Arco Travertino, about two miles from Rome, the villa of Quintus Servilius Silanus, who was Consul in 1809, was dis‑ covered, and close by were found at the same time the remains of a Christian church, with an entrance into the catacombs. Baron de Reaumont, the Prussian Minister at the Court of Tuscany, has arrived here to hold the ad interim management of the Prussian Legation during the absence of Baron de Theil, who has left for Berlin. The number of strangers now in Rome is unusually great, the majority being Russians and Poles. The weather is exceedingly mild for the season of the year."

A letter from Rome, in the Indipendente of Turin, says : "The news from the province of Ancona is bad : several assassinations and acts of violence have been committed, and nineteen persons arrested upon suspicion. The Pope is to hold a consistory on the 16th or 19th instant, in which he will appoint nine Spanish and also some Italian bishops. Prince Lucien Bonaparte, the son of the Prince of Canino, is to be received into holy orders on the 13th by the Pope, and to say his ﬁrst mass on the following day. The Grand Duchess Helen intends staying here four months ; she has taken an hotel on the Piazza del Popolo for 35,000f. Queen Christina, who is also expected here, will inhabit the palace of the Spanish Ambassador. M. de Kisseleﬀ, the Resident Minister of Russia, has already opened his saloons for the winter season."

A STORY FROM MUNICH.—The Courrier de Paris relates the following somewhat singular and not very probable anecdote: “ A few days ago, a gentleman, walking through the Charles Strause at Munich, and having on his arm a large cloak, happened to stop opposite the oﬃce of the Mont‑de‑Piété . He was immediately accosted by a female, one, it appears, of several who watch near those establish‑ ments at Munich for the purpose of gaining a triﬂing sum by pledging articles for persons who feel ashamed of enter‑ ing those places themselves. 'Ah! mein herr,' said the woman, 'you do not like to go in there yourself, and yet you perhaps wish to pledge your cloak. Give it to me, I will get you a good sum on it.' 'You will render me a ser‑ vice,' replied the gentleman, after a moment's hesitation, 'take the cloak, and I will wait here until you return.' At the end of ﬁve minutes, the woman returned, and handed to the gentleman ten ﬂorins, the sum lent on the cloak. 'Thank you, my good woman,' said the owner of the cloak, 'and now by way of commission put these ten ﬂorins in your pocket, and take these,' giving her eleven more, 'and redeem the cloak and pay the interest.' The woman was at a loss to understand all this, but she did as she was told, and on her return, as she was handing over the cloak to its owner, a company of soldiers passed by, who presented arms to the gentleman, whom the astonished woman then found was no other than King Louis. On his return to the palace, his Majesty sent for his tailor, and rated him soundly for charging eighty ﬂorins for a cloak on which he could only borrow ten ﬂorins."
Law Intelligence.
COURT OF CHANCERY.—DECEMBER 23.
BEFORE THE LORD CHANCELLOR.
Perry‑Herrick v. Attwood.

The arguments in this appeal, which have occupied the attention of the Court for a considerable time, were to‑day concluded. The facts of the case have been already reported, the points in dispute being the priority of certain encumbrances upon the Hylands estate, belonging to Mr. Attwood. The appeal was from a decision of the Master of the Rolls.
BEFORE MR. COMMISSIONER FONBLANQUE.
BANKRUPTCY COURT, LONDON. — DECEMBER 23.
In Re Lazarus Samson.
The Lord Chancellor aﬃrmed the decision of the Court below, and dismissed the appeal with costs.

The bankrupt was a merchant of Houndsditch. His accounts extend from January 1, 1856, to November 3, 1857, and contain the following items : Dr. Unsecured cre‑ ditors, £37,773. ; creditors holding security, £12,147. ; liabilities, £16,347. ; proﬁts, £1,696. ; surplus, January 1, 1856, £2,302.—Cr. Property held by secured creditors, £11,900. ; other property, £19,314. ; balance upon consign‑ ment account, £17,247. ; good debtors, £53. ; losses, £2,801. ; trade expenses, £1,149. ; house expenses, £1,453. The secured creditors include the Ottoman Bank, £10,420., the bank holding Joseph Levy's draughts on the bankrupt, £10,420., and a quantity of loose diamonds and other articles, of the value of about £9,400. A note is aﬃxed to the proceedings, setting forth that these diamonds were handed by Messrs. Posno and Co., of Constantinople, to Mr. Levy for disposal, and for better security were deposited by them with the bank on quitting England, with instruc‑ tions to the eﬀect that should certain parties who had been negotiating for their possession agree to take them at the price required by Mr. Levy, they were to be handed over ; the bank were to pay Posno and Co. their claim for them, and place the diﬀerence to Mr. J. Levy's account, as agent to Mr. Samson. The bank now state the diamonds were deposited as further security for their account, and refuse to give them up to Posno and Co., who claim them as their property. The bankrupt's liabilities include his accept‑ ances to J. Levy £440., and for which he states he has not received any consideration, and of his losses £2,779. are on shares. The property given up includes £2,500. in the form of sundry shares and scrip, also diamonds £4,000. ; and the whole is valued at about £18,000., subject to realisation.
Mr. Lawrance, for a creditor, asked for an adjournment. Accounts were required from Constantinople ; a goods account was also required.—Adjournment ordered.
The Court and Cabinet.

The Queen, with the Princess Royal, drove out on Wed‑ nesday morning. His Royal Highness the Prince Consort accompanied her Majesty on horseback. Major‑General the Hon. Chas. Grey and Captain du Plat were in atten‑ dance. The Earl of Clarendon left the Castle in the fore‑ noon. On Tuesday evening her Royal Highness the Duchess of Kent, attended by Lady Anna Maria Dawson and Lady Augusta Bruce, dined with her Majesty. The Earl of Clarendon, Lady Caroline Barrington, and Lieu‑ tenant‑Colonel the Hon. J. Strange Jocelyn, Scots Fusilier Guards, had the honour of being included in the royal dinner party.
The Earl Beauchamp and Lord and Lady Raglan are passing the season at Madresﬁeld Court, Worcestershire.

The Marquis of Anglesey has entertained a select party, including Sir John V. Shelley, Captain Little, Mr. George Payne, &c., during the past week at Beaudesert, near Lich‑ ﬁeld. The circle separated on Saturday. The noble Mar‑ quis will receive company during the holidays.
The royal baron of beef will this year be cut from a ﬁne Scot, fed by his Royal Highness the Prince Consort at Norfolk farm, and slaughtered by Mr. White. It weighs about 300 lbs.
The Metropolis.

THE BISHOP OF LONDON AT BETHNAL GREEN.—The Bishop of London again preached on Wednesday evening, within the densely populated parish of Bethnal Green, to a congregation comprising large numbers of the poor. The time of service was ﬁxed for eight o'clock, at which hour the church of St. Peter's was thronged by persons a con‑ siderable proportion of whom were evidently not regular church‑goers, and of whom it might be doubted whether they ordinarily attended any place of worship at all. Pro‑ bably curiosity to see a bishop was a motive more powerful with many than the devotional feeling, but throughout the service all were most attentive and orderly. The Bishop selected as his text the 6th of Luke, 20th verse : “ And he lifted up his eyes on his disciples, and said. ' Blessed be ye poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.'” The theme to which the preacher applied himself was, “ What was the peculiar blessing of being poor ?” This subject, one perhaps of peculiar diﬃculty in such an assembly, was skilfully and most feelingly illustrated by his Lordship in simple and earnest language, which went to the hearts of all present. "It is very well, you will say, for the rich to speak of the blessings of poverty. Nothing is easier for a man who never knew what hunger was, and who always had a full supply of the good things of this earth, to talk about the blessings of being poor.” Thus the Bishop adopted the most popular argument of the class he addressed, and replied to it by dwelling upon the fact that his and their Lord had chosen to be born among and to mix with the poor, and by pointing out that, as the poor could not look on their earthly homes with the same degree of satisfaction as the rich, their minds might be led to think more of a home which was in store for all Gos people, and in which there would be perfect happiness and perfect rest, so that in this way poverty might be a blessing. The congregation were reminded that their life here was but a passing journey, which would be ended in a few years at the longest ; that they were simply here like travellers stopping in an inn for a single night ; and that it might be very well for them to be placed in positions which were not pleasant in them‑ selves, but which might bring a real blessing with them. A few remarks appropriate to the closing year, and a refer‑ ence to the glorious news which had been diﬀused through‑ out the city that evening, that our countrymen and women in India had through Gos great mercy been saved from the perilous position in which they had so long been placed, concluded a most impressive address. Prayers had been previously read by the Rev. J. G. Packer, Incum‑ bent of St. Peter's, and at the conclusion of the service the Bishop announced that the Wednesday evening services thus inaugurated by himself would be continued every week at the same hour, so as to enable the working classes to attend.—Times.
The Provinces.

The Edinburgh Express states that Miss White, who has returned to this country from Genoa, was married on Saturday to a young Italian, of literary pretensions, named Signor Alberto Mario, with whom she became acquainted in Genoa.

THE CONVICT BRIGHT.—NOW the case is over, there are numerous anecdotes going the round of the town about Mr. Bright. It is said that of bills a very large number are regularly forged by some parties requiring them. A story is told of one person now well to do, who makes it no secret that he himself repeatedly dealt in such things. He narrates one case where he went to his banker's with a bill, on which was a name which he had been using for some time. The banker looked at it, and laying his ﬁnger on the forgery, said querulously, “That name again. Can't you give us another name. I am tired to death of seeing that one.” The person took the hint, destroyed the bill, went oﬀ to the nearest stationer's shop, got another blank bill, ﬁlled it up, wrote on it the acceptance of a ﬁctitious person whose place of residence was said to be at Birmingham, and a quarter of an hour after the ﬁrst bill was refused he got the new one discounted. It is said that instances of this kind are not rare, and Mr. Bright's case is only alluded to in connection with it to give an idea of the extent to which forgeries are practised.—Hull Advertiser.

DARING ROBBERY.—Early on the morning of Friday last, the 18th instant, a most daring robbery was per‑ petrated at Measham, near Ashby‑de‑la‑Zouch. Mr. Lewin, a draper, of that place, on retiring the previous night, left his shop with the contents, as he supposed, perfectly secure. On rising the next morning, at his usual hour, he found the shop had been entered, and stock taken to the value of between £200. or £300. The entrance had been eﬀected by the door at the back of the shop. A hole had been drilled with a centre bit, large enough to enable a person to open the inside fastenings ; and from several circumstances, it seems clear that at least one of the robbers was well acquainted with the premises. A person named Mosley is in custody on suspicion of being concerned in the robbery. The Derbyshire police are actively engaged in investigating the aﬀair, and are of opinion that the robbers were Bir‑ mingham men, and that the property was conveyed to that town.—Manchester Guardian.

SUPPOSED MURDER.—A few days ago some particulars were given in the Times respecting the discovery of some remains at Middleton, Norfolk, which were thought to be those of Mr. John Bell, who disappeared from that place about eight years ago, and who, it is now supposed, was murdered. The adjourned inquest took place yesterday at Middleton, before Mr. Wilkin, District Coroner. Many witnesses were examined, but their evidence was principally of a conjectural character, and nothing positive was ascertained. A purse was produced, which was identiﬁed as having formerly belonged to Mr. Bell. A witness, named Collison, deposed that while at work at Middleton, in November, 1849, he heard a great deal of scuﬄing and groaning near the place where the remains have been found, and afterwards, when Mr. Bell was missed, the wit‑ ness mentioned the circumstance to two persons, but nothing more speciﬁc arose out of this witness's testimony. The Coroner, in suggesting an adjournment, referred to the statement made by Collison, which he said was exceedingly important, and he believed they were on the threshold of a startling enquiry. He wished it to be publicly known that at the time Mr. Bell disappeared—and there could be no doubt that he had been foully murdered—bills had been issued oﬀering a reward of £220. for the conviction of the guilty person or persons. He should cause those bills to rëissued, and adjourn the inquest for a fortnight.— Times.

THE DOUBLE MURDER AT WARLEIGH, NEAR BATH.— At the Taunton Assizes, on Wednesday, Thomas Miller, a miserable‑looking man, was indicted and charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the wilful murder of Sarah Border, at Warleigh, on the 10th, of October. The prisoner, when called on to plead, made no answer, and by the direction of the learned Judge, a plea of not guilty was recorded. The facts were very simple. In the course of the night pre‑ vious, and on the day in question, the prisoner had mani‑ fested various aberrations of intellect. He said the Philis‑ tines were coming upon him, that he had been ﬁghting with the Indians, and that angels had been ﬂoating before his eyes. He complained that the deceased woman had charged him with being the man who had perpetrated the Leigh Woods murder, and made other statements for which there appeared to be no foundation. In the course of the evening, Border and his wife, who were servants in the employ of the same gentleman as the prisoner, and who lived at a cottage a short distance from him, hearing of his state, went down to enquire after him. At the time they arrived, his mother had left him for a few minutes, to go upstairs and attend her husband, (who had also been in‑ sane,) and on the Borders knocking at the door, the prisoner rushed out upon them with a knife. He inﬂicted a cut in the throat of the woman, and another in the abdomen of the man, from the eﬀects of which they both died within a very short time. The prisoner also cut his own throat, and stabbed himself in the belly with a penknife ; but these injuries, though severe, had not proved mortal. The only question in the case was the state of mind of the prisoner at the time ; and abundant evidence was given to show he was insane, and consequently irresponsible for his acts. The Jury without hesitation, acquitted the prisoner on the ground of insanity, and he was ordered to be detained until her Majesty's pleasure respecting him be known.—Daily News.
Table Talk.

Rosa Madiai and her husband, whose imprisonment in Tuscany made them famous some years since, now keep a depository for the sale of Bibles and religious books at Nice ; and like many other refugees from all parts of Italy love Sardinia as a land of toleration and constitutional liberty.

There is something solemn in such an event as is announced in foreign musical journals. We allude to the retirement of Dr. Spohr, at an advanced age, from active life. This took place late last month, at Cassell, when the composer conducted his "Jesonda," at the theatre, and was afterwards greeted by his old comrades and subordi‑ nates after the cordial German fashion.—Athenœum.

We have occasionally transferred to our columns valuable letters from the seat of war in Oude, addressed to the Saturday Review. We regret to learn from our con‑ temporary that the writer of those letters, who was an oﬃcer of the Madras Artillery, was killed at Lucknow, in the midst of the bloody passage from the Alumbagh to the Residency.

We read in the Leader :—“ The Marquis of Normanby's version of the incidents of 1848 will not remain unan‑ swered. M. Louis Blanc is preparing for the press a formal exposure of the inaccuracies contained in the diplomatist's narrative. Written in the English language, and inspired throughout by English feeling, this work will probably procure for its author such an English recognition as he never yet obtained. It will prove him to be not only a master of English art, but an adept in English habits of thought."

COPYRIGHT IN PICTURES.—The committee appointed by the Society of Arts to enquire into the state of the law in reference to copyright in pictures, will, we understand, hold their ﬁrst meeting in the course of a few days. The fol‑ lowing gentlemen have already consented to serve on the committee : Sir C. L. Eastlake, P.R.A., T. H. Hurlstone, (President of the Society of British Artists,) J. F. Lewis, (President of the Society of Painters in Water Colours,) John Bell, D. Roberton Blaine, F. S. Cary, H. Cole, C.B., Dominic Colnaghi, C. Wentworth Dilke, Roger Fenton, William Fladgate, George Godwin, F.R.S., Owen Jones, John Leighton, J. Linnell, W. Mulready, R.A., G. Scharf, jun., and William Tooke, F.R.S.

DEATH OF HERR KŒNIG.—We regret to hear of the death, at Paris, of the celebrated cornet‑á‑piston player. He has lately been one of the principal supporters of Jullien's concerts, and composed many favourite pieces of music, including the famous “Post‑horn Galop.” For some years he was the senior partner in the ﬁrm of Kœnig and Pask, the musical instrument manufacturers, of the Strand ; more recently he joined in the house of Chappell and Co., of Regent Street, and was connected with that ﬁrm at the time of his death. He attended the rehearsals of Jullien's orchestra at the beginning of the present sea- son, but was overtaken by illness, and by the advice of his physicians he gave up his engagement, and repaired to Belleville, the residence of his father‑in‑law, near Paris, for change of air, and it was there that his death took place.— Daily News.

HOW TO FALL ASLEEP.—The great point to be gained, in order to secure sleep, is to escape from that clinging, tena‑ cious, imperious thought, which in some cases of wakeful‑ ness, has possession of the mind. Various methods have been suggested by diﬀerent authors to diﬀuse the thoughts. Our own method, and one which we imagine conduces most naturally to lead the mind into easy dreaming, is to ima‑ gine a journey over some familiar path, bringing successively into the mins eye the scenery at each portion of the journey ; an exercise which rarely fails of success in a short space of time. Dr. Binn, in his “ Anatomy of Sleep,” describes his process as follows : “ I turn my eyeballs as far to the right or left, upwards or downwards, as I can without pain, then commence rolling them slowly with the divergence from a direct line of vision around in their sockets, and continue doing this until I fall asleep, which occurs generally within three minutes, and always within ﬁve at most. The immediate eﬀect of this procedure diﬀers from that of any other of which I have ever heard to pro‑ cure sleep. It not merely diverts thought into a new chan‑ nel, but actually suspends it. I have endeavoured innu‑ merable times, while thus rolling my eyes, to think upon a subject, and even upon that which before kept me awake, but I could not. As long as they were moving round my mind was a blank. If any one doubt this, let him try the experiment for himself. Let him pause just here and make it. I venture to assure him that if he makes it in good faith, in the manner described, the promise of ‘ a penny for his thoughts,’ or for each of them, while the operation is in progress, will add very little to his wealth.”—Scientiﬁc American.

FORTHCOMING CHRISTMAS AMUSEMENTS,—Drury Lane opens on Boxing Night, under the management of Mr. E. T. Smith, who, as usual, has retained Mr. E. Blanchard as the author of his pantomime, and Mr. Beverley as his scenic artist. Mr. Blanchard has again endeavoured to engraft a moral upon his fun—his pantomime this year is called “ Little Jack Horner ; or Hsrlequin A B C,” and is intended to elucidate the triumphs of intelligence over ignorance. The grand " eﬀe" will be a Coral Pavilion, built by Imagination, for Intelligence, her visitor, and in it Mr. Beverley is said to have surpassed all his previous eﬀorts. There will be a double pantomime company, Messrs. Flexmore and Bolino acting as clowns.—“ The White Cat” is the popular subject chosen by the author of the Princess's pantomime.—At the Haymarket, Mr. Buckstone is his own Christmas author, and has chosen “The Sleeping Beauty in the Wood” for his theme.—Mr. William Brough, who last year achieved such a success with “ Conrad and Medora” at the Lyceum, has this year been retained for the same theatre. He has now chosen the Persian romance of “ Lalla Rookh” for his subject. In the succeeding harlequinade Messrs. Tom Matthews and Stilt will be the principal attractions.—“ The Doge of Duralto, or the Enchanted Eyes,” is the title of Mr. Robert Brough's burlesque at the Olympic. Mr. Robson, of course, will sustain the principal character.—The “ union of burlesque and pantomime,” which up to last year formed the specialite of the Adelphi, is continued. Mr. Selby has found material in the loves of “ Cupid and Psyche” for the opening, and Mr. B. Webster is under‑ stood to have contributed the comic scenes.
Correspondence.
CURRENCY MADE EASY.
To the EDITOR of the DAILY POST.
Sir,—Will you oblige an old trader by printing the en‑ closed lines, by “ John Taylor,” with the two notes at foot, in one of your next numbers.
December 9th, 1857.
I remain, yours truly, THETA.
MONEY FOR THE MILLION.
“ We have money for the few ; ‘Tis the usurer’s device : Let's have money for the many, With gold at market price.”—Ballad.

Let bullion warrants represent the gold By weight, lodged in the bank, or some stronghold. The varying balances of foreign trade May, by these warrants, through the post be paid, Leaving the bullion in the bank or tower, For those to claim who hold the warrant's power.

Meanwhile let gold in legal tenders ﬁnd Its market price, like goods of every kind : Then will all classes pay the taxes ; then A fair day's wage be given to working men. With legal tenders we shall banish crises ; With competition check excess of prices.

The Bank directors promise, day by day, With gold for half their notes all claims to pay ! Exchequer notes are in themselves complete, They hold their value as a tax receipt, And need no promise from Threadneedle Street. Such notes the Monarch only can create : The power that makes the money rules the State.
These propositions are in verse conveyed, That rhyme and reason may the memory aid In teaching—for the funds, loom, sail, and plough, Gols market price must be our safeguard now.
† A permanent issue of Exchequer notes, to the amount of ﬁfteen or sixteen millions, might equally relieve the productive classes, but it would be less economical to the country.

*An Exchequer bill (or a note, without interest,) “is to be current, and pass in any of the public revenues, aids, taxes, or supplies, or at the receipt of Exchequer in Westminster, after the 5th day of April next." Exchequer bills for £5. and £10. were issued in 1696, and for £10. continued to be issued till 1741, during which time bank notes were not issued for less than £20. Bank notes were a legal tender from 1797 to 1819, in which notes gold found its market price. No law existed before 1816, requiring taxes to be paid in gold or in notes of equal value with gold.
To the EDITOR of the DAILY POST.

Sir,—The free and dispassionate discussion of the cur‑ rency question must, within proper limits, be a useful occu‑ pation both of your space and of your correspondents' time, and thus sanctioned, I venture a rejoinder to “ E. F. G.’s” letter in your issue of Friday last.

Having, as he says, contrary to my guess, really asked himself as to the aim and object of the currency system established by Sir Robert Pees measure, my remark now is that he has misapprehended the facts of the case. Sir Robert Peel did not vouch for his propositions, if enacted, having full power to prevent ﬂuuations in trade, but only held that they were " calculated" to do so. The word is quoted by your correspondent, and therefore to argue as though that had been aimed at, which on the face of it would be an absurdity, and not to be accomplished by any kind of regulations whatever, is utterly futile. When Sir Robert Peel said, as your correspondent goes on to quote, that his measures “would give steadiness to the character of our resources, inspire conﬁdence in the circulating medium, diminish (mark, diminish, not absolutely prevent,) all inducements to fraudulent speculations and gambling, and ensure its just reward to commercial enterprise conducted (mark again, conducted,) with honesty and secured by patience,” he did anything but promise either wonderful or ridiculous eﬀects ; so far from doing so he could hardly have enforced the abiding necessity for prudence and honesty in more appropriate or impressive language. Sir Robert Peel meant to secure the convertibility of bank notes, and to prevent thereby an over issue of them ; these were the two essential objects of his measures, and his measures have herein proved eﬀective.

After this I must persevere in saying our currency sys‑ tem has not failed, and cannot fail. We may well hope it will not be altered ; and we may have some doubt‑ whether it can be advantageously supplemented.

Your correspondent is a little too sanguine when he con‑ cludes that I shall not “ hold to the doctrine that the pound of ﬁfty years ago promised to pay a given quantity of gold,” and that “it circulated under the idea and expec‑ tation of being redeemed in gold.” I cannot possibly recede from a statement so notoriously founded on fact, and so easily veriﬁed. What, I would ask, did the Bank ﬁnd it impracticable to give in exchange for its notes when the Suspension Act of 1797 passed ? If it was not metal—say gold or silver, what was it ? “ E. F. G.” makes a sad con‑ fession when he says “ he never troubled himself as to what a pound was.” He ought to attach some meaning to the word.

Since the question is put to me, I will state that, accor‑ ding to my perception of the matter, the present state of diﬃculty which the country is in arises from “ mistaken, foolish, or dishonest transactions.” Quite enough has come to light to establish the existence of these causes of disaster and suﬀering.

What a stumbling‑block is the supposed ﬁxed price of gold ! It is tiresome to reïterate that it is not ﬁxed. It cannot be ﬁxed in gold of the same quality ; it cannot be quoted in gold of the same quality. The price of a thing must always be given in some other thing, and the price of gold has never been so ﬁxed. What “ E. F. G.” illustrates by the Exchequer Bill transaction is nothing more or less than the receiving a given quantity of gold, and being bound to return it at a future period, and at that future period producing the same or similar gold ; and how, as far as the gold is concerned, there can be either gain or loss, it puzzles me to ﬁnd out. When the Bank buys gold with its notes, and afterwards, when those notes come in, pays them with the same gold, neither proﬁt nor loss attaches to the transaction, so far as the exchange of the gold goes ; and this is all we have to argue about. Surely, there should be no diﬃculty here.

As to the rate of interest, we may remark that that simply marks the value of money at diﬀerent times and under diﬀerent circumstances. No legislative enactment deter‑ mines the rate of interest, which is another expression for the price of money, but that natural law, the law of supply and demand, regulates it. This law would aﬀect any sort of money equally with gold, if not arbitrarily increased or decreased, a thing not to be tolerated, let the pretence be what it may.

I need not follow your correspondent further, but I will add that real money must consist of a commodity, and that this commodity should be supplied in the way of trade, and ought not to be supplied or sought in any other way. Such a mode of suppling money is natural and simple, like that of supplying food and clothing. Government should not interfere with the former any more than with the latter, beyond ﬁxing the standard of value constituting it a legal tender and requiring nominal money to be convertible into real money. There is a vague notion, but a vague notion ﬁrmly ﬁxed in the minds of some, that Government ought to provide the money required by the country ; but if this was true, much more necessary would it be that Govern‑ ment should provide the food and clothing required by the country, for we could do better without currency than with‑ out capital, especially the capital now spoken of.
December 21, 1857.
Yours obediently, L D. E.
THE OPINION.
To the EDITOR of the DAILY POST.

Sir,—You are more than half right about the opinion of the Attorney‑General. I have good authority for saying that it was in the Dean's hands on Friday last, one day at least before he wrote the letter aﬀecting deference to the decision. The opinion, I need scarcely say, is obtained on a partial statement of facts. I also wish Mr. Slaney may get it.
ONE WHO KNOWS ALL ABOUT IT.
To the EDITOR of the DAILY POST.
RAILWAY ACCIDENTS.

Sir,—Will you allow me. through the medium of your valuable paper, to suggest to the directors of railways the propriety of adopting some method by which the passengers may be forewarned of an approaching danger from collision ; and it occurs to me that a sound diﬀerent to that of the whistle might be conveyed along a train, which, on being heard by the passengers, would give them in some measure a chance of protecting themselves from those serious con‑ sequences which so frequently take place, and of which, at present, they are seldom allowed even a moment's notice.
H. C,
Bromsgrove, December 23rd, 1857.
I am, Sir, your obedient servant,
THE THEATRE.
To the EDITOR of the DAILY POST.

Sir,—As an old subscriber to the Journal, and now Daily Post, I have to complain of one omission in the advertising department of those papers. Why is it that there have been no Theatre advertisements, or local theatrical notices lately? If the reason is a private one, of course you cannot state it ; but the absence of them prevents all knowledge of what is going on at the Theatre by parties who, like myself, do not read the street bills and placards, and who yet would like occasionally to treat themselves to a visit there. I am, Sir, yours most respectfully,
C. J.
Birmingham, December 24, 1857.
[We cannot answer the question, for the simple reason that we are totally unaware of the cause. It is the pleasure of the Manager, we suppose.—ED. Daily Post.]
THE GROCERS AND THE CHRISTMAS BOXES.
To the EDITOR of the DAILY POST.

Sir,—Will you me permit me to make a suggestion to the grocers respecting the Christmas Box question ? I will not attempt to argue the merits of the subject here, nor stop to discuss the claims of the “ old, old custom ” to continue any longer wearying and vexing the souls of men. One thing, however, is certain ; the public generally will ascribe the withholding to a spirit of stinginess. I by no means think that this is the real cause of this, as old Polonius would say, “defect,” and would suggest to the grocers of the town the propriety of raising a sum equal to (or above,) what would have been expended in giving Christmas Boxes, and dividing it among the institutions of the town. The Midland Institute, the Aston Hall movement, &c., would be none the worse for such an addition to their funds ; and such a course would for ever banish from the minds of the public the foolish opinion which they now hold upon the subject of the grocers and Christmas Boxes.
I am, Sir, yours respectfully, ONE OF THE PUBLIC.

Sir,—I beg to call your attention to the very neglected and dirty state of Monument Lane ; more particularly from the end of Plough and Harrow Lane to the Reservoir Road. The dirt and mud are such at times as to make it almost impassable.

GENERAL HOSPITAL, December 24th. — Physician, Dr. Bell Fletcher. Surgeon, Mr. Bolton. Visiters : Messrs. T. W. Blakeway and J. Ledsam. In‑patients admitted, 39. Accidents and urgent medical cases, admitted without recommendation, 14. Out‑patients admitted, 134. Accidents and urgent medical case, admitted without recommendation, 103. Weekly attendance, 904.
YESTERDAY.
BEFORE MR. REGISTRAR WATERFIELD.

In re Elizabeth Swinnerton. Stoke‑on‑Trent, victualler —A meeting for the choice of assignees, Mr. J. Smith appearing for the bank‑ rupt. Mr. Richard Heath, of Stoke‑on‑Trent, designer, was appointed sole assignee. Amount of debts proved about £200.

In re Edward Jones, Welsh Frankton, timber merchant.—This was also a meeting for choice of assignees. Messrs. James and Knight attended as agents for Mr. Wace, of Ellesmere, solicitor ; and nominated Mr. Richard Burlton, of Ellesmere, ironmonger, and Mr. Thomas Thompson, bookseller, of the same place. Debts proved £286.

In re Thomas Arnold, Shrewsbury, veterinary surgeon.—Meeting for the choice of a new assignee. On the nomination of Messrs. James and Knight, Mr. William Stanford Pipe Wolferstan, banker, of Uttoxeter, was chosen.
BEFORE LEIGH TRAFFORD, ESQ., JUDGE.
Birmingham County Court.

THE CASE OF THE SWEEP AND HIS CARRIAGE — Barton v. Watkins.—This rather singular aﬀair has twice been before this Court, and has already been fully reported in the Journal. To‑day it came on again on an adjournment, and occupied his Honour's attention for a long time. But we shall now give a brief report, as all that its interest deserves. Plaintiﬀ, who retained Mr. East, is a master sweep at Hockley, and defendant, for whom Mr. Hawkes appeared, is a coach and carriage manufacturer, Hockley Works. The action was brought to recover £6. 10s. as the price of a sweep's hand‑cart, built to order by Mr. Watkins for Barton. We may note that at the ﬁrst hearing the declaration stated that this cart had been made of old material, that it was unﬁtted for the sweep's purpose, &c. To‑day, however, that having been en‑ entirely disproved by satisfactory testimony for the defendant, the declaration allowed that the wood was split as to the panels, and that in place of being a proper and substantial thickness, the sides of the vehicle were merely framed, and really formed of very thin material. For the plaintiﬀ it was said that the thickness of these were but a quarter of an inch, whilst the defendant's witnesses said they were an an inch and three‑eighths. This arose, it would seem, from the sides having been, as before stated, pannelled or framed, in place of solid wood sides. The matter standing in this position, and many respectable coachmakers being called, who, misled by external examination, said it was substantially built, the vehicle itself was brought into Court and underwent a rigid examination. It was made clear to the satisfaction of the Judge,the thin covering over the thick stays being ripped oﬀ, that the two panels outside and inside were made of very thin wood. As to the splits or cracks, their existence or otherwise was also the subject of much contradictory evidence, and need not be further referred to, as the point in the case was against the proper thickness of the panels. The fairness of the charge was not disputed. After hearing the testimony or many witnesses, amongst others that of the man who made the vehicle, and who swore the panels were cracked ; and on the other side of defendant's manager,who stated that thin framing of two portions of wood was the usual plan, because, in fact, it made a carriage sides stronger. His Honour, who had seen the constructive state of the sweep's carriage, and heard the remarks of the advocates, said, “ I shall give the plaintiﬀ a verdict, and in the course of the day I shall give what I consider to be the proper amount of damages." Mr. Hawkes had thought that the plaintiﬀ having had the vehicle in use for a couple of months, was not entitled to get back its full cost ; whilst Mr. East, arguing that the thing was utterly valueless for the purposes and business of a sweep, asked positively for the £6. 10s. as claimed. At a subsequent period of the day the learned Judge awarded the sweep the sum of £6. 10s. The carriage to be given up to the maker.

THE ALLEGED WATCH ROBBERY CASE.—Bentley v. Brookes, (the elder.)—This matter, heard some time ago, and reported at the time, stands thus : Plaintiﬀ, who retained Mr. Hawkes, is a retail brewer, Bloomsbury, and some months ago took to the defendant, a watch maker, in Broad Street, a watch to repair, worth £5. Mr. Brookes, at the ﬁrst hearing, said that on Good Friday, having his shop shut up of course, about six o'clock at night he removed his stock of watches, as customary, to his bed room. When the family retired to rest, about eleven o'clock, it was found, so the defendant said, that the bed room window had been forced from the outside, and the stock of watches, including Mr. Bentley's, taken away. Supposing, as the defendant stated, that a felony had been committed, and that by such course the claim of the watch owner, Mr. Bentley, was barred by law, then of course the verdict at the ﬁrst hearing would have been for the defendant, Mr Brookes. But the learned Judge was not satisﬁed with the evidence as it stood at the ﬁrst hearing, that such felony had been established. An adjournment accordingly took place, in order that the evidence of the police, whose assistance was resorted to, might be heard.—To‑day, Detective Kelly said that after making a careful examination of the premises of Mr. Brookes, he found that the window (bed room sash) had been forced from the inside. Some instrument had been placed under the frame at the bottom, and thus when the prizing took place the breakage of the brass fastening of the sash followed, and the window then might easily be opened. But the most important part of Kelly's evidence stood thus. Over the front shop was a ﬂat roof, covered with lead sheeting, and this roof reached to the bed room window referred to as being broken open, and to the room from where the watches (ﬁve or six,) were said to have been stolen. On the front part of this ﬂat roof, twelve feet from the ground, Kelly found marks of nailed boots, with the toe marks towards the front of the shop ; but by the window, where similar marks would have been made had a man stood close by whilst he prized the sash, no mark whatever was perceptible. At the bottom, by the shop door, some marks were seen on the dirt, and some marks over the spouting, which ran by the side of the roof referred to. To‑day the defendant had no other evidence to oﬀer, and after hearing Mr. Hawkes, his Honour was of opinion that after hearing Kelly's testimony, he could not say that plaintiﬀ's watch had been feloniously taken by means of an entrance from the outside by thieves in the ordinary way, and therefore the verdict must be for Mr. Bentley, for the sum claimed.
Birmingham Police Court.
YESTERDAY, Before the Mayor, Mr. Phillips, Mr. Lloyd, and Mr. Sargant.

THE ASSAULT ON A LICENSED VICTUALLER BY A POLICEMAN. —A few days since we gave the facts attendant upon a savage and unprovoked attack made by Police‑constable Smith upon Mr. W. Wildgoose, landlord of the White Swan, in Moseley Street. Mr. Wildgoose procured a summons against his assailant, and the case was to have come on before the Magistrates on Friday last ; but on that day Mr. Harding, retained for the defendant Smith, being engaged at Warwick Assizes, the matter stood adjourned until to‑day. However, on its being now called on, Mr. Harding said that having only returned from the Assizes on the preceding evening, he had not had time to take the necessary steps to procure the attendance of an essential witness for the defence, a man named Rowe, living in Moland Street. It appeared that no money for expenses had been given to Rowe, and this perhaps accounted for his non‑appearance. Mr. Suckling, retained for Mr. Wildgoose, said that he was quite ready then to go on with the case ; all com‑ plainant's witnesses were present. It was, however, ﬁnally arranged that the case be called on the ﬁrst thing on Monday morning next, Mr. Suckling remarking that he assented to such course on the clear understanding that no attempt should be made to throw the matter over the period of the approaching Sessions. Smith was in Court, as was also Mr. Wildgoose, with his head still bandaged up. Smith has been suspended.

AN ATTEMPT TO PROVIDE FOR CHRISTMAS WHOLESALE.—A slim youth, decently dressed, named George Stringer, was brought up, charged with having stolen nearly the whole carcass of a sheep from the shop of Mr. Clarke, butcher. The evidence taken went to show that the prisoner had lifted down his expected prize, when he was hailed by some one, and dropping the Christmas meat was making oﬀ, when he was stopped and given into custody. The oﬃcer who had charge of the case said that Mr. Clarke was too busy to attend to‑day, (market day,) and the matter stands again adjourned until Saturday. The mutton was brought wholesale into Court, and young Stringer, eyeing it eagerly, said, " I was forced to take it."

ASSAULTING A LITTLE GIRL.—A big burly fellow, in a smock‑ frock, named George Gilbert, a horse clipper, Gooch Street, was charged as above. The complainant, a little delicate‑looking girl, thirteen years of age, living with her parents in Navigation Street, named Elizabeth Morton, stated that on the preceding day the defendant met her near the Market Hall, and without the least provocation struck her with a stick on the face and across her back. Police‑constable Haverin, who took the brute into custody, said the child complained that her back hurt her sadly, and her cheeks were swollen from the blows inﬂicted. All the clipper had to say was that he was drunk. Mr. Lloyd said that it was a very gross case of assault, and defendant was ﬁned 20s. and costs, or in default twenty‑one days' imprisonment.

SINGULAR CHARGE OF HORSE STEALING.—A man named Joseph Husselwaite, a market gardener, from Lichﬁeld, was placed at the bar, and Detective Palmer said that, ﬁnding a valuable horse had been stolen from a person at Leeds, on the 7th of November last, he, from information received, went on the preceding night to Lichﬁeld, and found that the accused had had the stolen horse in his possession a few days previously. He had sold it, however, to his brother‑in‑law, also of Lichﬁeld. Palmer, on going to this per‑ son's house, found the animal, but the then owner was not at home, and the oﬃcer taking possession of the horse, conveyed it from the market gardener to Birmingham. Husselwaite's account was that he had bought the horse from some man for £15., and sold it to his relative for £19. Palmer, who obtained a remand until Saturday, in order to send to Leeds, added that he found the stolen horse was in the ﬁrst instance taken to the defendant's, at Lichﬁeld, but he not being at home the animal was taken to Birmingham, where it was kept for a fortnight, and then conveyed to Husselwaite's house, at Lichﬁeld. All he now said was a repetition of the story as to his purchase of the animal from a man whose name, however, if he knew he did not mention, and thus this singular matter stands at present.

BURGLARY IN THE NEW BROMSGROVE ROAD.—About half‑past twelve on the night of Wednesday, the house of Mr. Burt, bailiﬀ to Captain Sheldon, situated near Long Bridge toll‑bar, on the New Bromsgrove Road, was broken into by three men, who ﬁred several shots up stair at Mr. Burt as he was stepping down to ascertain what was the matter. The daring rogues, seeing that their shots took no eﬀect, beat a retreat, and made their way out of the house as expeditiously as possible. No property was missed. One of the burglars was tall and of a dark complexion, his clothes ﬁtting closely. Of the others no description can be given.

ROBBERIES.— At six o'clock on Wednesday morning the inmates of the house, No. 91, Bishopsgate Street, occupied by Mr. Richard Allen, were alarmed by a noise down stairs, and on going down to ascertain the cause, found that the house had been entered by means of skeleton keys, and robbed of a time piece, value £3.18s. The burglars made a clear escape.—About the same hour yesterday morning the house of Thomas Martin, Portland Street, Aston Manor, was entered by some rascal, the door being left on the latch, and a pair of trousers, two coats, and a waistcoat, carried oﬀ.—A quantity of beef other provisions were stolen, during Wednesday night, from the house of Robert Carter, back of 47, Graham Street. Access was gained by the cellar grating. In neither of the above cases have the thieves or the missing property been discovered.

Five years ago, when Christian's Pătes de Lichen ﬁrst came under our notice, we spoke favourably of their properties as a remedy for coughs, and all aﬀections of the throat arising from cold. Since that time they have become the favourite speciﬁc, and in this weather are almost as indispensable to the invalid as goloshes or a top coat. It is often remarked that every disease has its counteracting remedy, and in this case the axiom holds good ; for if the prevailing evil in Birmingham is a tendency to throat disease, the panacea, and it is a pleasant one, is provided in the Pâte de Lichen.—Manufactured by steam in the laboratory of Mr. Christian, and sold at his Dispensing Establishment, New Street, corner of Cannon Street,) Birmingham.— Birmingham Daily Post.
To the EDITOR of the DAILY POST.
MORE DIRTY WAYS.
CURRENCY.
Birmingham, December 24th, 1857.
I remain, yours truly, A CONSTANT READER.
Birmingham Bankruptcy Court.
Foreign Intelligence.
